qas.question: What's the minimum amount of copper a layer in a PCB can have to be considered "heavy copper"?
About how thick would a PCB layer be if it contained three oz. of copper?
What will a circuit board with heavy copper carry very well?
What would a PCB designer use heavy copper to make their circuit board resist?
Where does the heat go when it leaves heavy copper-plated vias?

plausible_answers.text: layers exceeding three ounces of copper

qas.question: The printed circuit board industry defines light copper as what?

plausible_answers.text: design and manufacturing circuit boards in order to increase current-carrying capacity as well as resistance to thermal strains

qas.question: PCB designers and fabricators often use light copper when?
What is the standard for determining current-carrying capacity of printed circuit board trees?

plausible_answers.text: determining current-carrying capacity of printed circuit board traces

qas.question: IAC 2152 is the standard for what?

context: The printed circuit board industry defines heavy copper as <b5_0>layers exceeding <a0_0>three ounces<a0_0/> of copper<b5_0/>, or approximately <a1_0>0.0042 inches<a1_0/> (4.2 mils, 105 μm) thick.
